newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Italian firm buys Argentine hamlet for safari center.
newsitem.headline: Italian firm buys Argentine hamlet for safari center.

text.p: An Italian holding group has bought a small village of adobe huts in the Argentine Andes foothills at $1 per hectare (2.5 acres) and plans to turn it into a safari centre, the daily Clarin said on Sunday.

Nettis Impianti Holding will turn 840,100 acres (340,000 hectares) in President Carlos Menem's La Rioja province into an "exotic safari (area) due to the incredible richness of its fauna," Nettis representative Angel Bolognesi told Clarin.

The daily said the purchase of the land in an isolated desert area, which includes Jague (pronounce hag-weh), a cluster of adobe huts where 500 people lead an austere life raising cattle, took place in 1990 but was kept secret until Nettis envoys visited the land last month.
"We are very worried," Nimia Cortez, director of the Jague school, told Clarin. "We've owned this land for 300 years now. We don't want to become an Italian province."
But Nettis told local authorities it will respect the peoples' lifestyles and will grant them property deeds to their huts and lots.
Jague Mayor Maria Elena Alvarez de Varas, however, was not impressed. She said she was ready to take the case to international organisations if the provincial government failed to block the deal.
